snippet: The conservation group Oceana said that genetic analyses showed 39 percent of nearly 150 samples of fresh seafood collected from 81 establishments in the city were mislabeled.
abstract: Study by researchers from the conservation group Oceana, using DNA testing, shows that fish is frequently misidentified on menus and in grocery stores in New York City; national supermarket chains had the best record for accuracy in seafood labeling; in some cases, cheaper types of fish were substituted for expensive species, but some of the findings represent public health concerns, like fish sold as white tuna that was not tuna at all but a potentially toxic species of mackerel.
lead_paragraph: The conservation group Oceana said that genetic analyses showed 39 percent of nearly 150 samples of fresh seafood collected from 81 establishments in the city were mislabeled.

headline.seo: Tests Call Mislabeled Fish a Widespread Problem in New York
headline.main: Tests Say Mislabeled Fish Is a Widespread Problem
headline.print_headline: Tests Say Mislabeled Fish Is a Widespread Problem
